TopicTitle: Ask the Mods questions about the Forums!

Articles.Content: Does it make sense to do that?
Can mods see through profile privacy, as in the ability to see if the user is active whether it is set to private or not, eg me, normal users cannot see if I am online or not, but can mods see?

> 
> Does it make sense to do that?

In my opinion, no. Why should NASA-inspired mods get a forum of their own, but not Russian/Soviet-inspired ones? And if you have those two, why not ESA and China? Soon you would have a subforum for every real life space program.

Sorry but I don't really see the benefit.

> 
> Can mods see through profile privacy, as in the ability to see if the user is active whether it is set to private or not, eg me, normal users cannot see if I am online or not, but can mods see?

Yes, moderators can see the online status of users that have chosen to hide it.

> 
> In my opinion, no. Why should NASA-inspired mods get a forum of their own, but not Russian/Soviet-inspired ones? And if you have those two, why not ESA and China? Soon you would have a subforum for every real life space program.

Seems something better served with tags, either in-forum or user-maintained.

[NASA] isn't that hard to type ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

It would basically be for all replicas that replicate past or modern space programs, from all over the world.

To what extent should OPs be responsible for keeping their threads on topic?

Is it possible to ever get infractions removed?

The OP shouldn't need to police the thread. That's what we're for. Hit the report button and let us deal with it rather than get into a possibly contentious situation yourself. 

> 
> Is it possible to ever get infractions removed?

Members are free to message the moderator that issued the infraction, and to take it up the chain of command if that is unsatisfactory. KasperVld's word is final, though. There is no appeal beyond him. Reversals do happen, but are rare. Remember, we are constantly talking things over in a chat while we work, and each infraction requires the approval of a more senior moderator anyway, so it's not coming from just one person, but rather reflects the effort of the team. For that reason, the seniors have rarely deemed it necessary to un-do a moderation action. 

> 
> *1- What is the funniest piece of spam you've ever come across on the forums?*

A badly translated recipe. 

> 
> ... Heater for warm milk to about 40 - 500C and the yeast pack it in, stirring , for 10 minutes purposes yeast blooms...

Yes, you want your "warm" milk to be 5 times the boiling point of water. 

> 
> *2- Does it take you a bit of thought when dealing out infraction or can you tell at a glance whether or not a person needs to get hit in the head with the ModHammer?*

We try to react to the post rather than the person. Our subjective impression of the poster shouldn't enter into it. We do look at that person's infraction history, though, for a pattern of similar behavior. 

> 
> *3- Have you ever moderated while drinking? If you have, did you know that buzzed moderating is drunk moderating?*

Some folks have participated in our internal chat while tipsy, but they know better than to take moderation action while under the influence. 

> 
> *4- Are you having a good day?*

Not bad, thank you, though nasty hot.

How do you moderators define "Personally Attacking?" I've seen two posts from one person critiquing ships rather.. vehemently.. and although I reported one, the other was removed by a moderator without a report. So as not to talk about the actions of a moderator towards one's post.. How long does it usually take you to issue an infraction?

What is the moderator hierarchy and how does it work?

Can you say where everyone ranks?

> 
> How do you moderators define "Personally Attacking?" I've seen two posts from one person critiquing ships rather.. vehemently.. and although I reported one, the other was removed by a moderator without a report. So as not to talk about the actions of a moderator towards one's post.. How long does it usually take you to issue an infraction?

It rarely takes more than a few hours, never more than a day that I've seen. I can't get into specifics of any particular incident, but you might remember that craft are not people, so:

"I think this craft is awful" is rude, but probably OK unless there are other circumstances.

"This craft is awful and you are awful for building it" is a personal attack and actionable.

Generally speaking, we don't take action against critiques of craft themselves, even if they are somewhat rude.
